elements.content: Over the past decade, the development in the valorization of biomass technologies keeps increasing because the biomass utilization for manufacturing fine chemicals and fuels has diverse advantages over fossil feedstock. The review focuses on the utilization of metal–organic framework-derived (MOF-derived) materials as effective solid catalysts for the valorization of biomass into platform chemicals. MOFs compose of abundant organic ligands and metal cluster, and additional functional groups, could be modified on ligands (or metal clusters) serving as active sites. On the other hand, MOFs could also be converted into porous carbons or metal oxide composites by calcination at nitrogen or air, respectively, for catalytic reactions. These MOF-derived catalysts feature advantages like high specific surface area, porosity, and active sites from mother MOFs. More importantly, stronger interactions between guests (i.e., metal or alloy NPs) and hosts (i.e., MOF-derived carbons or metal oxides) make these catalysts more efficient than conventional catalysts where guests are deposited on hosts by impregnation. We summarize the studies of lignocellulosic biomass conversion including (1) dehydration of sugars such as glucose, fructose, and xylose into furans, (2) hydrogenation of furans into fine chemicals, and (3) sugars into sugar alcohols using MOF-derived catalysts. The challenges and prospective of MOF-derived materials applied in biomass conversion are also described.

elements.content:
Valorization of lignocellulosic biomass into fine chemicals over a series of metal−organic framework-derived (MOF-derived) solid catalysts.

Lignocellulosic Biomass

Fossil feedstocks, which are coal, natural gas, and crude oil, are used to satisfy our energy requirements and to produce a variety of chemicals that enrich our lives. The difficulties with large-scale utilization of fossil feedstocks are the uneven geographical distribution of reserves, declining availability, and global warming. To avoid these problems with fossil feedstocks currently, lignocellulosic biomass is extensively used all over the world for chemical synthesis and energy applications. It has been suggested that biomass is the only reliable alternative source for replacing fossil feedstocks for the synthesis of chemicals and fuels by promoting environmentally benign pathways. Because biomass is renewable, abundant, and readily available, it is a carbon-neutral process upon biomass utilization, equally distributed, and has a lower impact on the environment. Hence, it becomes a natural choice for researchers to use lignocellulosic biomass as an alternate resource for fossil feedstocks.

elements.content: Lignocellulosic biomass is the most abundant form of biomass present with an annual production of ca. 170 billion metric tons. As shown in , it is composed of lignin (18%–28%), cellulose (40%–50%), and hemicellulose (20%–30%). Lignin is an aromatic polymer made up of methoxylated phenylpropane units, while cellulose and hemicellulose are polysaccharides. Cellulose is homopolysaccharide and made up of β-d-glucose units. Hemicellulose can be homo- or heteropolysaccharides, which are made up of pentose sugars, hexose sugars, and sugar acids linked together by β-(1→4), β-(1→3), and β-(1→6) glycosidic linkages. Hemicellulose is classified as xylan, mannan, xyloglucan, galactan, and arabinan depending on the cell-wall polysaccharide types.

elements.content: As hemicellulose is made up of various sugars such as glucose, xylose, mannose, galactose, arabinose, and rhamnose, recent studies demonstrate that hemicellulose present in this raw biomass could be efficiently converted into C5 sugar monomers. The xylan type of hemicellulose is most common, which is basically made up of xylose sugar. As is shown in , the hydrolysis of xylan produces xylose and arabinose as major C5 sugars which could be further converted into a wide variety of value-added chemicals, including xylitol and furfural. For instance, furfural has many applications in several industries such as lube oil refining, synthesis of phenolic resins, and pharmaceuticals, and the derivatives such as furfuryl alcohol (FOL) and methyl furan (MF) could be produced by hydrogenation of furfural (FAL), which further finds potential application as solvent and fuel. Extensive literature is available for the conversion of isolated hemicellulose into C5 sugars and furfural using solid acid, mineral acid, and acidic ionic liquid catalysts.

elements.content: Cellulose, on the other hand, is a homopolymer composed of glucose with a higher degree of polymerization (DP) = 100–2000 compared to hemicellulose (DP = 100–200). Cellulose is difficult to hydrolyze compared to hemicellulose and other saccharides because of the presence of inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonding between various anhydro-glucan units. This extensive hydrogen bonding of cellulose makes it a partly crystalline and robust material toward chemical reactivity. As presented in , various potentially important chemicals can be generated from cellulose. Cellulose is decomposed into glucose by hydrolysis. Further dehydration of glucose yields 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) which is a platform chemical used for the synthesis of a varity of industrially significant chemicals such hydrogenation into 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) via bis­(hydroxymethyl)­furfural (BHMF) intermediate and oxidation into 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) via furan-2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) ­and 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) intermediates. Furthermore, various significant chemicals such as γ-valerolactone (γ-GVL), levulinic acid (LA), and 1,6-hexanediols can be manufactured from HMF, too.

elements.content: Many catalysts have been reported for the biomass conversion to value-added chemicals such as mineral acids (HCl, H2SO4), organic acids (p-toluenesulfonic acid, maleic acid), solid acid catalysts (SAPO, HUSY, sulfonated carbon), zeolites (ZSM-5, HMOR), ion exchange resins (Amberlyst-15, Nafion), heteropoly acids (heteropoly tungstate, MOF-based heteropoly acid), metal supported catalysts (Ru/C, Pt/C, Pd/C), and ionic liquids ([BMIM]­[Cl], [C3SO3HMIM]­[HSO4]).

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as porous coordination polymers (PCPs), are a series of porous structures composed of metal ions/clusters (joint) and organic ligands (linker). The metal ions/clusters coordinate with multipodal organic ligands, forming secondary building units (SBUs). SBUs are arranged into a porous framework with particular morphology by sharing podals with each other. Most of the transition metals, post-transition metals, and lanthanides have been used as joints and coordinated with different linkers such as bi-, tricarboxylate-contained benzene rings and N-contained cycloalkane composites. The diverse combination of joints and linkers makes MOFs with different texture properties and morphology. Until now, more than 20,000 kinds of MOFs have been either synthesized or designed by simulation (e.g., ZIF-8, HKUST-1, MIL-53, UiO-66, and PCN-222). MOFs have features like large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area, large pore volume, and abundant Lewis/Brønsted acid/base sites, which make MOFs better material for catalysis, separation, storage, and sensing applications by either directly using MOFs or a combination of MOFs with polymers, metal oxides, graphene, porous carbon, cells and viruses.
elements.clean_text:
Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) and Their Derived Nanomaterials

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), also known as porous coordination polymers (PCPs), are a series of porous structures composed of metal ions/clusters (joint) and organic ligands (linker). The metal ions/clusters coordinate with multipodal organic ligands, forming secondary building units (SBUs). SBUs are arranged into a porous framework with particular morphology by sharing podals with each other. Most of the transition metals, post-transition metals, and lanthanides have been used as joints and coordinated with different linkers such as bi-, tricarboxylate-contained benzene rings and N-contained cycloalkane composites. The diverse combination of joints and linkers makes MOFs with different texture properties and morphology. Until now, more than 20,000 kinds of MOFs have been either synthesized or designed by simulation (e.g., ZIF-8, HKUST-1, MIL-53, UiO-66, and PCN-222). MOFs have features like large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area, large pore volume, and abundant Lewis/Brønsted acid/base sites, which make MOFs better material for catalysis, separation, storage, and sensing applications by either directly using MOFs or a combination of MOFs with polymers, metal oxides, graphene, porous carbon, cells and viruses.

elements.content: The diversity of MOF materials makes them potentially useful catalysts with various functionalities. Besides directly using the active sites in the framework of MOFs, functionalization of MOFs with other ligands or the thermal treatment of MOFs to make porous carbons or metal oxides are two types of popular MOF-derived catalysts (). The ligands on MOFs are either modified with functional groups or replaced with functional group-containing ligands. The functional group with ligands can change the microenvironment around the SBUs which has an apparent effect on the catalytic reaction. MOFs are inherent porous structures where the organic ligands and SBUs are placed along the edge of pores which could be regarded as a self-template. MOFs could be converted into porous carbons (PCs), metal embedded PCs, and porous metal oxides (PMOs) by annulling under an inert or oxygen-rich environment. The MOF-derived materials feature high specific surface area, porosity, and abundant active sites from mother MOFs. Moreover, by carefully selecting ligands and metal ions, the texture properties of MOF-derived materials could be customized for different applications. Until now, MOF-derived materials have been applied for catalysis, separation, energy storage, and so on owing to the advantages mentioned above. To the best of our knowledge, so far, MOF-derived materials have not been used as catalysts for hemicellulose conversion, while recent studies show the applications of MOF-derived materials for xylose dehydration and FAL hydrogenation into cyclopentanone (CPO) and FOL. In the case of lignocellulosic biomass conversion, MOF-derived materials have been reported as an efficient catalyst for hydrolysis of cellulose to glucose, isomerization of glucose, dehydration of glucose and fructose, hydrogenation of HMF, oxidation of HMF, conversion of fructose into DFF, etherification of HMF, etc.

elements.clean_text: 2  Synthesis of MOF-derived materials via functionalization and thermal treatment.

elements.content: The conversion of lignocellulose biomass into value-added chemicals and biofuels has been widely studied recently, and we attempt to provide a broad overview of lignocellulose biomass conversion using MOF-derived materials as catalysts. An overview of the recent fabrication of MOF-derived materials including functionalized MOF, porous carbons, metal embedded porous carbons, and metal oxides are provided, followed by a case study of the reactions including dehydration of sugars, hydrogenation of HMF and FAL, oxidation of HMF, etc. This review focuses on the efficient and economically viable processes and the modifications in the MOF-derived materials for the optimization of efficient biomass conversion. Various properties of MOF-derived materials are explained in detail and advantages of these materials for biomass conversion are reviewed. Although there are few reports on biomass conversion into value-added chemicals using MOF-derived materials because of the unexplored applications of MOF-derived materials for biomass conversion, this review would help readers find novel applications of MOF-derived materials and usability for biomass conversion as a catalyst for developing new economical, selective, environmentally friendly, and sustainable technology. Finally, the challenges and future trends and prospects associated with the development of MOF-derived materials are examined. This review is a beneficial source for guiding industrial and academic researchers working in the biomass and MOF research areas. Also, it will help readers to understand the proficiency of MOF-derived materials over conventional heterogeneous catalysts (e.g., zeolites) and homogeneous catalysts (e.g., mineral acids) when using MOF-derived materials in the field of biomass conversion.

elements.content: In this section, many MOF-derived catalysts will be introduced. These catalysts can be briefly divided into two groups: (a) MOFs with a functional group and (b) metal nanoparticles in MOF-derived carbons or in MOF-derived metal oxides. The synthesis of the catalyst is introduced and the advantages of MOF-derived catalysts in applications are discussed.
elements.clean_text:
MOF-Derived Catalysts

In this section, many MOF-derived catalysts will be introduced. These catalysts can be briefly divided into two groups: (a) MOFs with a functional group and (b) metal nanoparticles in MOF-derived carbons or in MOF-derived metal oxides. The synthesis of the catalyst is introduced and the advantages of MOF-derived catalysts in applications are discussed.

elements.content: Terephthalic acid is one of the popular organic ligands used in the synthesis of MOFs. A functional group-containing terephthalic acid could be used to synthesize the isoreticular MOF (IRMOF) with the same SBUs due to their similar topology while an additional function is given with a MOF framework. For example, zinc oxide clusters coordinated with terephthalic acid is IRMOF-1 (or MOF-5), while zinc oxide clusters coordinated with aminoterephthalic acid is IRMOF-3. The additional amino group could serve as a Lewis base in the catalytic reaction. Cmarik et al. synthesized a series of isoreticular UiO-66, including −H, −NH2, −NO2, −1,4-naphthyl, and −2,5-(OMe)2, and showed the effect of ligands on adsorption properties. The result showed that the functional groups change the adsorption heat and the water affinity, which leads to a different ability toward gas separation. Zhou and co-workers synthesized PCN-125 with various functionalized ligands (a). Different from Cmarik’s work, Zhou’s group modified terphenyl tetracarboxylates (TPTCs, ligands of PCN-125) by breaking TPTCs into a functional group-containing isophthalate (R-isoph, R represents methyl, amino, nitro, sulfo, etc). The R-isoph not only provides additional function for PCN-125 but also enlarges the pore size of PCN-125. The pore size was enlarged from 1 to 1.1 nm as 50% of H-isoph was added into the PCN-125-growth solution. As a comparison, two functional groups are modified on TPTCs (2R-TPTC), too. The R-isoph-containing PCN-125 showed higher CO2 uptake with lower heat of adsorption than 2R-TPTC-containing PCN-125, demonstrating that functional groups change the adsorption while the enlarged pore size is helpful for adsorption, too.

elements.content: Hupp and co-workers synthesized a squaramide moiety-containing biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate (squar-bpdc) and fabricated squar-UiO-67 as a hydrogen-bond-donating organocatalyst (b). The NMR spectrum showed that the ratio of squar-bpdc to bpdc was one on UiO-67. The free squaramide-based catalyst is easily deactivated due to a combination of detrimental intermolecular hydrogen bonding of the squaramide moieties, while squar-UiO-67 showed good catalytic activity even after several cycles. They demonstrated that the modification of the functional moiety on the ligand of MOF could prevent the deactivation of functional moiety since the ligands were separated by SBUs and well align in a 3D framework. However, part of functional group-containing ligands could not be used for synthesis of ISMOFs due to thermodynamically unfavorable characteristics.

elements.content: An alternative way to fabricate these kinds of thermodynamically unfavorable ligands is using solvent-assisted linker exchange (SALE) where the ligands in as-synthesized MOF are replaced by functional group-containing ligands in a favorable condition. For example, Kim et al. successfully fabricated a dual-functional group-containing UiO-66 (i.e., −Br and −NH2) by SALE. Takaishi et al. accessed new versions of robust porphyrinic MOF (RPM) by changing the pillaring linkers with SALE. RPM is composed of two types of porphyrins whose metal centers need not match. It looks like a chance to synthesize a series of dual-metallic RPMs for multistage chemical catalysis; however, the variety of metal ions using the conventional procedure is limited due to the thermodynamically unfavorable characteristic. A ZnZn-RPM was synthesized with the conventional procedure. Metal-free or metal-chelated ligands were used to replace the second Zn ligand with SALE. For example, ZnAl-RPM fabricated by SALE showed catalytic activity on a ring-opening reaction which could be achieved by ZnM-RPM synthesized with the conventional procedure (c).

elements.content: The functional group could also be grafted on ligands or SBUs of MOF to promote catalytic activity. Canivet et al. synthesized carboxylimidazolate-containing zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) and grafted dodecylamine on ligands. A hydrophobic shell around ZIFs was formed, which apparently prevents ZIFs from water adsorption. A better catalytic activity of Knoevenagel was achieved by grafting a hydrophobic group on the ligand of SIM-1 (isostructural ZIF-8, C10H10N4O2Zn). Goesten et al. also directly functionalized sulfate groups on ligands of MIL-53. On the basis of the assumption that the ligand was monosulfated, 50% of the ligands in MIL-53 became sulfated terephthalate. This procedure was processed on MIL-101, showing that 20% of the ligands were successfully sulfated, too. The sulfate groups on ligands showed good thermal stability and catalytic activity on esterification of acetic acid with butanol. MIL-101-H2SO4 showed a comparable turnover frequency on esterification to sulfuric acid, while it also demonstrated the recyclability which could not be achieved by a homogeneous mineral acid catalyst such as sulfuric acid.
elements.clean_text: The functional group could also be grafted on ligands or SBUs of MOF to promote catalytic activity. Canivet et al. synthesized carboxylimidazolate-containing zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) and grafted dodecylamine on ligands. A hydrophobic shell around ZIFs was formed, which apparently prevents ZIFs from water adsorption. A better catalytic activity of Knoevenagel was achieved by grafting a hydrophobic group on the ligand of SIM-1 (isostructural ZIF-8, C10H10N4O2Zn). Goesten et al. also directly functionalized sulfate groups on ligands of MIL-53. On the basis of the assumption that the ligand was monosulfated, 50% of the ligands in MIL-53 became sulfated terephthalate. This procedure was processed on MIL-101, showing that 20% of the ligands were successfully sulfated, too. The sulfate groups on ligands showed good thermal stability and catalytic activity on esterification of acetic acid with butanol. MIL-101-H2SO4 showed a comparable turnover frequency on esterification to sulfuric acid, while it also demonstrated the recyclability which could not be achieved by a homogeneous mineral acid catalyst such as sulfuric acid.

elements.content: Besides serving as active sites, the functional group-containing ligands could also serve as metal-binding sites for metalation. An isolated single atom-coordinated MOF was fabricated owing to the isolated ligands homogeneously aligned in MOF. Cohen’s group performed a series of metalation on MOF by modifying catechol groups on ligands of MOF and stabilizing organometallic ions. A robust UiO-66 was selected as the template, and a 2,3-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (or a 2,3-dimercaptoterephthalic acid) was used to replace the part of terephthalic acid in UiO-66 by SALE. The NMR spectrum showed that 75% of terephthalic acid was replaced by 2,3-dihydroxyterephthalic acid, while 40% of that was replaced by 2,3-dimercaptoterephthalic acid. Both noble metal and transition metal were chelated with catechol (or thiocatechol), showing an isolated metallic atom on every functionalized ligand from the X-ray absorption spectrum and electron spin resonance spectrum. The resulting catalysts demonstrated activities on regioselective functionalization of the sp2 C–H bond and secondary alcohol oxidation on various reactants. Besides the outstanding activity, the catalyst also showed stability in a recycling experiment which might be difficult to achieve by homogeneous catalysts.

elements.content: MOFs are assembled by coordination between SBUs and ligands, while the decoordination between SBUs and ligands processes in an acidic environment makes MOFs unstable during the catalytic reaction. Several kinds of MOFs are proposed to be stable in acidic environments, such as MIL-101, UiO-66, PCN-222, etc.; however, there are several thousand types of MOF which are not stable in acidic environments and could not be used for chemical catalysis. Thermal treatment is used to convert MOFs into diverse types of porous materials, including porous carbons (PCs) and porous metal oxides (PMOs) which are more stable than their mother MOFs. In addition, if the second (or third) metal ions were added upon synthesis, after thermal treatment, it would result in metal nanoparticle-embedded PCs or PMOs.
elements.clean_text:
MOF-Derived Catalysts via Thermal Treatment

MOFs are assembled by coordination between SBUs and ligands, while the decoordination between SBUs and ligands processes in an acidic environment makes MOFs unstable during the catalytic reaction. Several kinds of MOFs are proposed to be stable in acidic environments, such as MIL-101, UiO-66, PCN-222, etc.; however, there are several thousand types of MOF which are not stable in acidic environments and could not be used for chemical catalysis. Thermal treatment is used to convert MOFs into diverse types of porous materials, including porous carbons (PCs) and porous metal oxides (PMOs) which are more stable than their mother MOFs. In addition, if the second (or third) metal ions were added upon synthesis, after thermal treatment, it would result in metal nanoparticle-embedded PCs or PMOs.

elements.content: The synthesis of PCs has attracted much attention owing to the advantages of large specific surface area, conductivity, thermal stability, and chemical stability. PCs are typically synthesized from the direct pyrolysis of carbon-rich composites (e.g., biomass and polymer) followed by chemical or physical activation. The organic ligands in MOFs are separated and aligned regularly by SBUs. Besides, they can be regarded as the resource of carbon. Consequently, direct pyrolysis of MOFs followed by removal of SBUs provides an efficient way for synthesis of PCs.

elements.content: Xu’s group prepared MOF-derived PCs by pyrolysis of polymerized-furfuryl alcohol-stuffed MOF-5 and demonstrated a good performance on H2 storage. MOF-5 is composed of zinc oxide as SBUs and terephthalic acid as ligands. After pyrolysis under Ar flow at 1000 °C, the as-synthesized PCs showed amorphous carbon without the existence of a Zn element by X-ray diffractometry. The SBUs of MOF-5 (Zn4O) were reduced into a Zn metal at 800 °C followed by evaporation of the Zn metal. The MOF-5-derived PCs exhibit a high BET specific surface area of 2872 m2/g and a large pore volume of 2.06 cm3/g with hierarchical porous structures, which were comparable to the theoretical surface area of a double-sided separated graphitic sheet (2965 m2/g). Xu’s group further used ZIF-8 as a template, stuffed with polymerized-furfuryl alcohol followed by pyrolysis under Ar flow at 1000 °C. The furfuryl alcohol-stuffed ZIF-8-derived PCs showed a higher percentage of H2 storage (2.77%) than most of the carbon-based materials including activated carbons and MOF-5-derived carbons owing to the natural property of the ligands used for synthesizing ZIFs. The higher percentage of the C atom in the organic ligand (2-MIM) enhances the H2 storage of PCs.

elements.content: ZIF-8 is one of the eye-catching branches in MOFs for fabricating PCs because its organic ligand contains only C and N. One 2-methylimidazole ligand contains 34 wt % of N which is higher than that of 2,5-diaminoterephthalic acid (14 wt %). Direct carbonization of ZIF-8 into nitrogen-containing PCs (denoted as NPCs) has been reported widely as a good material for electrocatalysis and chemical catalysis. The nitrogen atoms on ZIF-8 were converted into pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, or quaternary-N (a). The pyridinic-N on NPCs serves as electrochemically active sites for enhancing the capacitive behaviors while graphitic-N serves as active sites for aerobic oxidation by formation of oxygen radicals on N–O2 adducts. In our previous work, we demonstrated that ZIF-8-derived NPCs showed a superior catalytic activity on oxidation of HMF to FDCA using graphitic-N as the active site.

elements.content: Synthesis of MOF-derived materials by thermal treatment. (a) Direct pyrolysis of ZIF-8 into nitrogen-containing porous carbons (NPCs) as catalyst. (b) Direct pyrolysis of ZIF-8/ZIF-67 hybrid nanoparticles into Co single atoms on nitrogen-doped porous carbon (Co SAs/N–C). (c) High resolution TEM image of Co SAs/N–C. Red circles represent Co single atoms. (d) Corresponding EXAFS fitting curves with schematic model of Co SAs/N–C, Co (purple), N (blue), O (red), and C (gray). Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016 John Wiley and Sons. (e) Direct calcination of MOF-embedded KIT-6 into metal-oxides@KIT-6 as catalyst. (f) High resolution TEM image of Co3O4@KIT-6 derived from ZIF-67@KIT-6. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2018 Royal Society of Chemistry.

elements.content: The functionalized MOFs could also be used as a template during thermal treatment. For instance, Fu et al. synthesized amine-containing UiO-66 and functionalized with glyphosine, a P-containing molecule, to form a P-containing UiO-66. After pyrolysis at 1000 °C, P-containing UiO-66 nanoparticles (NPs) became defect-rich carbon which is favorable for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The resulting P-containing PCs showed comparable limiting current density and halfway potential to that of platinum on carbon, a state-of-the-art electrode for ORR. The transition metals (Ni, Co, Fe) are used for graphitization of amorphous carbon. Because of the homogeneous distribution of SBUs and ligands, the MOF-derived PCs could be in situ graphitized into graphite using SBUs. Yamauchi’s group synthesized ZIF-8/ZIF-67 hybrid NPs and further converted them into graphitized PCs. ZIF-8-derived PCs show a high content of N with appreciable surface area, while the carbon is amorphous. On the contrary, ZIF-67-derived PCs show a high degree of graphitization, while a low content of N and low surface area was observed. The PCs derived from hybrid NPs showed comparable N content and surface area to ZIF-8-derived PCs, while the degree of graphitization is much higher than ZIF-8-derived PCs. The resulting catalyst exhibited a distinguishable specific capacitance owing to in situ graphitization.

elements.content: Metal composite NPs, including metal oxides and metals are widely used in catalysis and gas sensing applications. MOF-derived PCs have tunable porosity and specific surface area which is a benefit for the deposition of metal composites. The combination of metal NPs with MOF-derived PCs is demonstrated to have better performance than either PCs or metal NPs themselves. The metal NPs-containing MOF-derived PCs could be synthesized by either introducing a selected metal source into a MOF or a MOF-derived PC or directly converting the SBUs into metal NPs by thermal treatment.

MOF-derived PCs have tunable porosity and specific surface area which is a benefit for the deposition of metal composites. The combination of metal NPs with MOF-derived PCs is demonstrated to have better performance than either PCs or metal NPs themselves. The metal NPs-containing MOF-derived PCs could be synthesized by either introducing a selected metal source into a MOF or a MOF-derived PC or directly converting the SBUs into metal NPs by thermal treatment.

elements.content: Fischer’s group has summarized a series of methodology for introducing metal NPs into a MOF, including impregnation, solid grinding, and chemical vapor infiltration. Xu’s group demonstrated an improved incipient wetness impregnation to introduce single metal sources and bimetal sources into a MOF using the cosolvent method. The metal ions are dissolved in water which is in same volume with a total pore volume of MIL-101. Both MIL-101 and metal ion-containing water were suspended in hexane, becoming a MIL-101/water in hexane system. They demonstrated that by using a cosolvent method, the metal nanoparticles evenly distributed in a MOF with a narrower size distribution than using impregnation or chemical vapor infiltration. Furthermore, alloy metal NPs could be synthesized with the cosolvent method. In our previous work, we introduced Au NPs into ZIF-8 by a de novo approach where metal ions were infiltrated into a MOF during assembly of MOF. Our results also demonstrated an even distribution of Au NPs with narrow size distribution. We further converted the Au NP-embedded ZIF-8 into Au NP-embedded PCs by pyrolysis under a N2 environment. As shown in the previous section, the nitrogen atoms on ZIF-8 had many useful functions after pyrolysis of ZIF-8 into PCs; the nitrogen atoms on PCs changed the microenvironment of Au NPs and promoted the performance of Au NPs on the reduction of 4-nitrophenol into 4-aminophenol.

elements.content: Chen et al. directly carbonized ZIF-8 into NPCs. The abundant nitrogen atoms were used to stabilize palladium precursors, followed by reduction of Pd precursors into Pd clusters using H2 gas. The abundant nitrogen atoms on NPCs served two functions in the catalyst. It works as anchor point for Pd ions, while it also generates hydrogen bonds with water molecules by a lone pair of electrons, which makes the surface of carbon hydrophilic. The Pd-NPCs were used for cascade conversion of vanillin into 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol, demonstrating high conversion and selectivity. The results were attributed to the hydrophilic surface of Pd-NPCs since the intermediate vanillin alcohol is a hydrophilic molecule, while the reactant vanillin and the product, 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol are hydrophobic molecules. Li et al. similarly applied MOF-253 which is composed of 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid and aluminum as the template and decorated Pd NPs on MOF-253-derived NPCs for Knoevenagel condensation–hydrogenation process. The inherent N atoms worked as anchor points for Pd NPs and at the same time provided Lewis basic sites for a tandem reaction with a distinguishable result.

elements.content: Wang et al. directly used SBUs as a metal source and directly annulled MOF into MPCs. Ni-BTC (BTC: benzene tricarboxylic acid) was added with zinc ions during synthesis. As demonstrated by Xu, zinc-SBUs would evaporate during pyrolysis, generating cavities in the carbon structure. The zinc-SBUs act as pore-forming agents, making MOF-derived carbons porous by evaporating at 900 °C (pyrolysis). The porous Ni/C showed an improved electrocatalytic performance in hydrogen evolution reactions because the porous structure apparently reduced the charge transfer resistance in the carbon substrate, displaying a semi-double-layer capacitance for porous Ni/C. Li’s group further reduced the scale of the SBU-derived metal composites from NPs into isolated single atoms (b). Hybrid ZIF-8/ZIF-67 NPs were synthesized to dilute the density of Co atoms in a MOF material. The hybrid ZIF-8/ZIF-67 NPs were further annulled into Co single atoms on nitrogen-doped porous carbon (Co SAs/N–C) under an Ar environment at 900 °C (c). Co ions were reduced into Co atoms by carbon and stabilized by nitrogen, while Zn ions evaporated during pyrolysis. The EDS mapping of Co atoms in a different Z-axis reflected different intensity, indicating that the distribution of Co was homogeneous in 3-D space rather than on the surface. The simulated model showed that one Co atom coordinated with two N atoms and two C atoms, showing both the higher value of limiting current density and halfway potential in ORR owing to the strong interaction between Co-2N (d).

elements.content: Besides PCs and MPCs, MOFs could be converted into metal oxide, serving as active sites for catalysis and/or as hosts for immobilization of catalysts. Porous metal oxide structures (PMOs) are fabricated from SBUs. Because of the wide combination between SBUs and ligands, a desired PMO could be easily synthesized by selecting a desired metal precursor as SBU. For instance, Co3O4 NPs, CuO NPs, and TiO2 NPs were synthesized by calcination of ZIF-67 NPs, MOF-199 (HKUST-1), and MIL-125­(Ti) particles under an air atmosphere. Furthermore, not only monometallic PMOs but also bimetallic PMOs could be fabricated by using MOFs as the template. We delivered secondary metal precursors into MOFs by a de novo approach. Cu­(NO3)2 was introduced into MIL-125­(Ti) upon synthesis. Cu-containing MIL-125­(Ti) was directly calcined into CuO-embedded mesoporous titania tablets (CuO@MTs). The element distribution showed homogeneous distribution of Cu atoms in a mesoporous titaina tablet. The results of H2-temperature programed reduction (H2-TPR) and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) showed that some parts of CuO NPs were inserted into TiO2 layers, which promoted the performance of CuO@MTs on photocatalytic hydrogen evolution by effective charge transfer between CuO and TiO2.

elements.content: However, because of the rapid and severe reaction between MOF and oxygen, like carbon combustion and metal oxidation, the MOF-derived PMOs were not sufficiently well controlled to generate nanomaterials. To prevent the severe reaction, Li’s group synthesized ZIF-67 in mesoporous silica, KIT-6, followed by calcination under air at 250 °C to remove organic ligands (e). Co3O4 NPs were confined within the channel of KIT-6 with an average size of ca. 2 nm (f). On the contrary, Co3O4 NPs aggregating on the outer surface of KIT-6 had an average size of ca. 13 nm, indicating the function of the porous substrate on controlling the particle size of the metal oxide. The MOF-derived metal oxide composites showed catalytic activity on oxidation of HMF into FDCA under milder conditions. The results could be attributed to the separated SBUs by ligands and confinement of metal oxide in the silica matrix.

elements.content: In this section, we introduced three types of MOF-derived materials (i.e., PCs, MPCs, and PMOs) that can be fabricated by thermal treatment. The heteroatoms on ligands provide additional function for catalyst. The overgrowth of metal seeds is prevented because of separated and well aligned SBUs in a MOF material. A catalyst with catalytic activity to selected reactions could be fabricated by choosing a favorable MOF containing SBUs whose derivative has activity to that reaction. The flexible combination of ligands and SBUs makes MOF-derived materials efficient alternative catalysts in biomass conversion.

The flexible combination of ligands and SBUs makes MOF-derived materials efficient alternative catalysts in biomass conversion.

elements.content: UiO-66- and MIL-101­(Cr)-based MOF-derived materials have been significantly used in biomass conversion so far. Both UiO-66 and MIL-101­(Cr) are proved to be robust MOFs which are stable against acid and high temperature. The MIL-101­(Cr) features large pore size (1.2 and 1.6 nm), open metal sites, and the feasibility of functionalization for catalytic biomass conversion. For example, the Brønsted acidity can be provided to MIL-101 by functionalizing the organic ligand (terephthalic acid) with −SO3H groups.
elements.clean_text:
Biomass Conversion over MOF-Derived Catalysts

Hydrolysis of Saccharides into Sugar Monomers

UiO-66- and MIL-101(Cr)-based MOF-derived materials have been significantly used in biomass conversion so far. Both UiO-66 and MIL-101(Cr) are proved to be robust MOFs which are stable against acid and high temperature. The MIL-101(Cr) features large pore size (1.2 and 1.6 nm), open metal sites, and the feasibility of functionalization for catalytic biomass conversion. For example, the Brønsted acidity can be provided to MIL-101 by functionalizing the organic ligand (terephthalic acid) with -SO3H groups.

elements.content: Hydrolysis of cellulose was studied using MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H by Kitagawa’s group, where the results showed a very low yield of monosaccharides (5%) in water. The inferior yield of monosaccharide (5%) is observed because of the lower Brønsted acidity and heterogeneous nature of the catalyst which causes diffusion limitations for bulky cellulose. The Brønsted acidic MOF (MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H) used for cellulose hydrolysis was synthesized directly from 2-sulfoterephthalate monosodium salt and chromium oxide and has lower acidity (1.8 mmol/g). The difficulties in synthesizing a highly Brønsted acidic MOF is its stability in the presence of higher acid concentration because most of the MOFs are not stable under strongly acidic conditions. The recycle test demonstrated the stability of MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H even after testing a recycling experiment 13 times which indicates that this MOF is extremely stable compared with a popular solid acid catalyst like Amberlyst-15.
elements.clean_text: Hydrolysis of cellulose was studied using MIL-101(Cr)-SO3H by Kitagawa's group, where the results showed a very low yield of monosaccharides (5%) in water. The inferior yield of monosaccharide (5%) is observed because of the lower Brønsted acidity and heterogeneous nature of the catalyst which causes diffusion limitations for bulky cellulose. The Brønsted acidic MOF (MIL-101(Cr)-SO3H) used for cellulose hydrolysis was synthesized directly from 2-sulfoterephthalate monosodium salt and chromium oxide and has lower acidity (1.8 mmol/g). The difficulties in synthesizing a highly Brønsted acidic MOF is its stability in the presence of higher acid concentration because most of the MOFs are not stable under strongly acidic conditions. The recycle test demonstrated the stability of MIL-101(Cr)-SO3H even after testing a recycling experiment 13 times which indicates that this MOF is extremely stable compared with a popular solid acid catalyst like Amberlyst-15.

elements.content: MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H was also used as a catalyst for glucose isomerization for the first time in 2014 by the Kitagawa group. Both MIL-101­(Cr) and MIL-100­(Cr) are chromium-based MOFs, while chromium oxide coordinated with trimesic acid in MIL-100­(Cr) and chromium oxide coordinated with terephthalic acid in MIL-101­(Cr). MIL-101­(Cr) exhibited a better performance than MIL-100­(Cr) because the aperture size of MIL-101­(Cr) (1.2 and 1.6 nm) was larger than the kinetic diameter of glucose (0.8 nm), making easy diffusion of glucose into the pore of MIL-101­(Cr). The electron-withdrawing functional group such as −NO2 and −SO3H presenting on the ligand of MIL-101 can enhance the activity of MOF for glucose isomerization. Because the electron-withdrawing groups increase the Lewis acidity of SBUs, MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H not only produce higher fructose yield but also shows 100% glucose and fructose recovery. Conversely, electron-donating groups (−NH2 and −(CH3)2) increase electron density on the SBUs resulting in the decrease in Lewis acidity. Hence, electron-donating groups on the ligands decreases the activity of MIL-101­(Cr) toward glucose isomerization. Similar to their previous work, MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H showed good stability in a recycling test for glucose isomerization. The results demonstrate that MOF-derived materials can be a potential catalyst for hydrolysis reactions.

elements.content: The dehydration of biomass-derived C5 and C6 sugars (fructose and glucose) is an important reaction for the synthesis of platform chemicals such as FAL and HMF which could be further converted into various value-added furan derivatives by hydrogenation and oxidation reactions. Recently, the synthesis of FAL and HMF has attracted much attention, and extensive research work for the production of furans from C5 and C6 sugars have been reported. Several catalysts have been reported for the dehydration reactions of fructose and glucose into HMF apart from MOF-derived materials such as acidic ionic liquids (ILs), metal complexes and oxides, heteropoly acid-based materials, mineral acids and organic acids, metal halides, ion-exchange resins, zeolites, functionalized carbonaceous materials, functionalized mesoporous materials, etc. The employment of MOF-derived materials for fructose and glucose dehydration reactions has been extensively studied because in many cases MOF-derived catalysts are easy to separate and recycle from the reaction mixture in addition to their high catalytic ability. Moreover, MOF-derived materials can provide Lewis as well as Brønsted acidity which is useful for the glucose dehydration reaction, as shown in . The Lewis acidity (LA) comes from open metal sites present at the SBUs, and Brønsted acidity (BA) comes from acid-functionalized ligands. The presence of Lewis acidity and Brønsted acidity helps the conversion of glucose into HMF in a more selective pathway and hence inhibit side reactions. In addition, the presence of a regular porous structure helps the diffusion of sugar molecules.

Conversion of Sugars into Furan Derivatives

Moreover, MOF-derived materials can provide Lewis as well as Brønsted acidity which is useful for the glucose dehydration reaction, as shown in . elements.clean_text: 3  Pathways for Glucose Cyclodehydration into HMF

elements.content: A MIL-101­(Cr)-based MOF-derived material was first employed in a THF/H2O solvent system for glucose dehydration to HMF. MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H exhibited 29% yield of HMF from glucose. The MOF catalysts (MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H and MIL-101­(Cr)-NO2) are selective for HMF synthesis compared to conventional catalysts such as sulfuric acid and Amberlyst-15. On the other hand, the specific surface area, X-ray diffraction peaks of catalyst, and the yield of HMF after four cycles of reaction remained unchanged, demonstrating a good potential of MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H for glucose dehydration. MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H was also reported for continuous reaction (performed in fixed bed reactor) for glucose dehydration in γ-GVL/H2O (9:1 v/v) solvent and showed improvement in yield of HMF (45%) with a short reaction time of 3.5 h. Fukuoka and co-workers demonstrated the dehydration of glucose into HMF using phosphate-modified NU-1000 (material prepared with equimolar phosphoric acid concentration PO4/NU(eq) and half-equimolar phosphoric acid concentration PO4/NU(half)). The glucose dehydration using unmodified NU-1000 showed only 2.3% yield of HMF and 19% yield of fructose in H2O at 140 °C in 5 h, whereas PO4/NU(half) showed 15% yield of HMF under similar reaction conditions. The modified phosphate molecules work as a negative molecule to poison the Brønsted acid sites on zirconia (SBUs), which generate undesired glucose transformation (e.g., humins) during the reaction. However, PO4/NU(eq) showed results similar to bare NU-1000, indicating that the Brønsted acid sites still have some positive effect on the reaction. Hence, the PO4/NU(half) catalyst exhibits higher HMF yield compared to unmodified NU-1000 and PO4/NU(eq). Furthermore, the chromium-based porous coordination polymer and its sulfonic-functionalized derivatives was successfully employed by Du et al. for glucose dehydration which showed over 99% conversion of glucose and 80.7% yield of HMF in water/THF/NaCl solvent system in 4 h at 180 °C. This higher yield of HMF was possible because of the presence of Brønsted and Lewis acidity in the catalyst. Furthermore, NaCl helps increase the immiscibility between water and the THF phase, thus lowering side reactions. A five-times recycling test showed only a 3% loss of yield (from 80% to 77%) of glucose on the catalyst in the glucose dehydration. Presently, this is a promising catalytic system reported using the MOF-derived material for the synthesis of HMF using glucose.

elements.content: Fructose dehydration into HMF using a MOF-derived catalyst was reported recently, too. Hatton et al. reported the synthesis of a MOF-polymer composite (MOF-PMAi-Br, produced using MIL-101­(Cr) surrounded in a cross-linked poly­(N-bromo-maleimide)) for fructose dehydration with a high HMF yield of 87% in DMSO solvent. The higher yield (87%) with MOF-PMAi-Br compared to PMAi-Br (50%) could be attributed to the 3D structure of MOF which unfolds the polymer chain and exposes bromine to fructose. In , the dehydration reactions of sugars into furans are presented using MOF or MOF-derived materials as the catalysts. As shown in , the dehydration of fructose into HMF was performed in DMSO using various MOF-SO3H as solid acidic catalysts at 120 °C for 1 h. The catalytic efficiency of MOF-SO3H increases in the subsequent order as MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H (90%) > UiO-66-SO3H (85%) > MIL-53­(Al)-SO3H (79%) in fructose-to-HMF dehydration. The catalyst with higher sulfonic acid groups among MOF-SO3H catalysts showed better performance; however, the MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H catalyst was not very active for the dehydration of glucose into HMF because of the inefficiency of the MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H catalyst for the glucose isomerization into fructose. For xylose dehydration into FAL, very limited reports are available using MOF-derived materials as the catalyst. The MOF-based mixed matrix membrane reactor (Zn2­(bim)­4-PMPS) was used by Weishen and co-workers for the xylose dehydration and obtained 41% FAL yield in 9 h at 140 °C.

The use of a heterogeneous MOF and MOF-derived material such as MIL-101­(Cr), UiO-66, PCP­(Cr)-SO3H, etc. for the dehydration of sugars offers higher surface area, metal sites, and bifunctional acid sites such as Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The MOF and MOF-derived materials are also easily recyclable and offers similar activity in a recycling experiment in most of the cases. Although several MOF-derived materials are used for the dehydration reactions of C6 sugars (glucose and fructose) to synthesize HMF, there is no successful MOF-derived material which can efficiently convert glucose sugar into HMF in an environmentally benign solvent (H2O) under milder reaction conditions. To make HMF synthesis sustainable and more economically viable, selection of H2O as a reaction solvent and glucose substrate over fructose is necessary due to its lower cost and wider supply compared to fructose.

elements.content: Furan-based chemicals like HMF and FAL are regarded as platform materials which could be further converted into value-added products via hydrogenation, oxidation, ring-opening, hydroxylation, or a combination of the above reactions. Here, we disclose the advantages of MOF-derived materials as the catalysts for the conversion of furan-based materials into fine chemicals.
elements.clean_text:
Upgrading Furans into Fine Chemicals

Furan-based chemicals like HMF and FAL are regarded as platform materials which could be further converted into value-added products via hydrogenation, oxidation, ring-opening, hydroxylation, or a combination of the above reactions. Here, we disclose the advantages of MOF-derived materials as the catalysts for the conversion of furan-based materials into fine chemicals.

elements.content: Rafael et al. employed MIL-45B as a sacrificial template for the synthesis of a Fe–Co non-noble catalyst. This catalyst was used for the oxidation of HMF to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) which exhibited very high yield of DFF (99%) under mild conditions. The unique hollow structure of the MOF-derived Fe–Co catalyst favors the adsorption of HMF and quick desorption of the formed DFF due to weak interactions with MOF-derived Fe–Co which results in higher yield of DFF. Furthermore, the catalyst is stable under reaction conditions and showed no drop in DFF yield during the recycling test. The same research group also reported the MOF-derived Fe3O4 catalyst for the conversion of fructose into DFF in a one-pot fashion, as shown in . This catalyst was stable under reaction conditions and showed complete conversion of fructose with DFF selectivity >99% in 5 h at 100 °C. The Fe/C–S synthesized from MIL-88B offers strong adsorption of HMF and weak adsorption of DFF because the two formyl groups of the DFF molecule improve the electrostatic repulsive interaction with the catalyst surface which helps in the HMF conversion and decreasing side reactions which help in the HMF conversion. Moreover, the Fe/C–S catalyst has magnetic properties which make the easy separation of the catalyst from a reaction mixture. Furthermore, the atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analysis result showed no metal leaching in the reaction solution.
elements.clean_text: Rafael et al. employed MIL-45B as a sacrificial template for the synthesis of a Fe-Co non-noble catalyst. This catalyst was used for the oxidation of HMF to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) which exhibited very high yield of DFF (99%) under mild conditions. The unique hollow structure of the MOF-derived Fe-Co catalyst favors the adsorption of HMF and quick desorption of the formed DFF due to weak interactions with MOF-derived Fe-Co which results in higher yield of DFF. Furthermore, the catalyst is stable under reaction conditions and showed no drop in DFF yield during the recycling test. The same research group also reported the MOF-derived Fe3O4 catalyst for the conversion of fructose into DFF in a one-pot fashion, as shown in . This catalyst was stable under reaction conditions and showed complete conversion of fructose with DFF selectivity >99% in 5 h at 100 °C. The Fe/C-S synthesized from MIL-88B offers strong adsorption of HMF and weak adsorption of DFF because the two formyl groups of the DFF molecule improve the electrostatic repulsive interaction with the catalyst surface which helps in the HMF conversion and decreasing side reactions which help in the HMF conversion. Moreover, the Fe/C-S catalyst has magnetic properties which make the easy separation of the catalyst from a reaction mixture. Furthermore, the atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analysis result showed no metal leaching in the reaction solution.

elements.content: Cyclopentanone (CPO) is an important chemical used in the manufacturing of insecticides, perfumes, medicines, rubber chemicals, and solvent in the electronics industry. Generally, CPO is produced by oxidation of cyclopentene and catalytic vapor-phase cyclization of adipic esters or 1,6-hexanediols, while recently the synthesis of CPO was also carried out from FAL which is a renewable chemical obtained from biomass and hence has received much interest. The MOF-derived CuNi@C catalyst was reported for an efficient conversion of FAL into CPO. The pyrolysis of Cu-based MOFs impregnated with Ni­(NO3)2 is used for the synthesis of a MOF-derived CuNi@C catalyst. The porous carbon used could prevent the accumulation of metal particles and acts as a support for the metal. The CuNi0.5@C catalyst provides the highest catalytic performance with 97% CPO yield and over 99% FAL conversion. It was found that the Cu@C catalyst is useful for the FAL rearrangement and produces CPO with 52% yield and showed a 79% conversion of FAL. On the other hand, the addition of Ni in HKUST-1 showed dramatic improvement in the performance of the catalytic activity (99% FAL conversion with 97% CPO yield) owing to the synergistic effect of metal NPs. However, when Ni–Cu bimetallic catalysts supported on SBA-15 were used for FAL hydrogenation, 39% CPO selectivity with a 46% FAL conversion was observed within 4 h at 160 °C (4 MPa H2). These results suggested that MOF-derived CuNi@C could perform better compared to the bimetallic Ni–Cu@SBA-15 catalyst. Furthermore, the selective hydrogenation of FAL into CPO was reported using a Ru nanoparticle supported on an acidic MOF (Ru/MIL-101) catalyst. Ru/MIL-101 exhibited complete conversion of FAL within 2.5 h at 160 °C (4 MPa H2) with very high CPO selectivity (96%). The activity of Ru/MIL-101 was compared with Ru supported on active carbon (Ru/AC) under similar reaction conditions; inferior results are seen (72% furfural conversion with 40% CPO selectivity) owing to the inherent acidic microenvironment provided by Lewis acid sites on MIL-101. A catalyst characterization (AAS analysis) study revealed no metal leaching observed in the reaction solution. Moreover, the crystal structure of the catalyst remains unchanged after the reaction.

elements.content: In hydrogenation reactions of FAL, it was found that MOF-derived CuNi@C can help to increase the concentration of reactants around the active metal site and also contribute to hydrogenation. Bimetallic CuCo/C was fabricated with a similar procedure by Xiao’s group, and the catalyst was applied for hydrogenation of FAL into FOL. The conversion was achieved is 99% with 97.3% selectivity of FAL. Compared with bimetallic MPC, MOF-derived Cu/C showed only a 46.6% conversion with 81.3% selectivity of FAL. CuCo/C demonstrated the stability of the catalyst in the recycling test by showing an unapparent difference of selectivity between each cycle. These two results suggested that MOFs are potential templates for synthesis of MPCs since metal precursors are tightly confined in MOF, which could prevent the overgrowth of metal NPs during pyrolysis, and secondary metal sources could evenly distribute around SBUs, which would lead to an even distribution of bimetallic NPs. A further hydrogenation of FAL would make the product become THFA. Another case of hydrogenation of FAL to THFA was done by Wang’s group who prepared Ni-based MPCs for hydrogenation of FAL by direct pyrolysis of Ni-MOFs under nitrogen. The TEM images showed an even distribution of Ni NPs on a carbon substrate owing to the formation of Ni carbides which play a crucial role on preventing the aggregation of Ni NPs. The MOF-derived Ni/C showed total conversion of FAL into tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) as MOFs were pyrolyzed at 500 °C. The amounts of nickel active sites and nickel carbide were changed with the pyrolysis temperature. Ni active sites dominate the reaction, while nickel carbides stabilize nickel NPs. The Ni NPs were stable at 400 °C during the reaction, while the amount of active sites was not enough for complete conversion of FAL into THFA. At 600 °C, most of Ni carbides were converted into nickel active sites for hydrogenation, while the Ni NPs became unstable due to the inexistence of Ni carbide. It suggests that the coordination between SBUs and ligands could stabilize the metal NPs by forming a metal–carbon bond.

elements.content: Ning et al. synthesized a 2D Co-based MOF which was pyrolyzed under an argon environment from 150 to 800 °C. The oxidation condensation of FAL to 3-(furan-2-yl-)-2-methylacrylaldehyde showed bimodal distribution of conversion and selectivity over MOF-derived materials. The first peak value of conversion and selectivity showed up as MOFs were pyrolyzed at 300 °C. According to thermogravimetric analysis, the SBUs are confined by organic ligands, while the moisture covering SBUs was removed as pyrolysis temperatures were lower than 400 °C. The unsaturated active sites on SBUs were exposed to reactants (FAL) for oxidation condensation reactions. As the temperature was increased to 800 °C, the framework started to decompose, and SBUs transformed into α-Co NPs immobilized on a carbon matrix. The α-Co NPs showed better conversion and selectivity on the oxidation condensation of FAL than the unsaturated active sites on SBUs. Although the catalysts pyrolyzed at different temperatures showed different activity for the oxidation condensation reaction, both catalysts demonstrated good recyclability in the reuse test.

elements.content: The selective hydrogenation of HMF into 2,5-dihydroxymethyl-tetrahydrofuran (DHMTHF) was reported using Pd immobilized on amine-functionalized MOF [Pd/MIL-101­(Al)-NH2] catalyst. This catalyst offers preferential adsorption to intermediate 2,5-dihydroxymethylfuran (DHMF) formed during the hydrogenation compared to HMF adsorption. Because of the enhanced hydrophilic nature of DHMF, it adsorbs extensively over the Pd/MIL-101­(Al)-NH2 catalyst which results in further hydrogenation of DHMF into DHMTHF. The optimized reaction condition showed 96% DHMTHF yield with complete HMF conversion using the Pd/MIL-101­(Al)-NH2 catalyst. The other catalysts such as Pd/MIL-53­(Al)-NH2, Pd/MIL-53­(Al), and Pd/MIL-101­(Cr) exhibited lower activity than the MIL-101­(Al)-NH2 catalyst. The higher activity in the case of MIL-101­(Al)-NH2 was seen because of well-dispersed Pd NPs over MIL-101­(Al)-NH2, and the −NH2 functional group cooperates for selective hydrogenation of HMF into DHMTHF. The presence of the −NH2 group in the frameworks helps the formation of highly well-dispersed Pd NPs and also preferential adsorption of the DHMF intermediate through hydrogen bonding formed during the hydrogenation reaction.

elements.content: As per our knowledge, no reports have been published yet for the valorization of real lignin using MOF-derived catalysts. However, few reports are available on the conversion of lignin model compounds. The model compounds used so far have included benzyl phenyl ether (BPE), 2-phenylethyl phenyl ether (PPE), diphenyl ether (DPE), vanillyl alcohol (VAL), etc.. Two types of isorecticular MOF-74­(Mg) (IRMOF-74 (I, II)) were used efficiently to cleave β-O-4 and 4-O-5 linkages of phenyl ethers. To further promote the selectivity of the catalyst, titanium and nickel were doped into the MOF framework. Compared to other commercial catalysts, the doping of titanium (Ti) and nickel (Ni) in these catalysts improved the conversion and selectivity for hydrogenolysis versus ring hydrogenation.
elements.clean_text:
Valorization of Lignin

As per our knowledge, no reports have been published yet for the valorization of real lignin using MOF-derived catalysts. However, few reports are available on the conversion of lignin model compounds. The model compounds used so far have included benzyl phenyl ether (BPE), 2-phenylethyl phenyl ether (PPE), diphenyl ether (DPE), vanillyl alcohol (VAL), etc.. Two types of isorecticular MOF-74(Mg) (IRMOF-74 (I, II)) were used efficiently to cleave β-O-4 and 4-O-5 linkages of phenyl ethers. To further promote the selectivity of the catalyst, titanium and nickel were doped into the MOF framework. Compared to other commercial catalysts, the doping of titanium (Ti) and nickel (Ni) in these catalysts improved the conversion and selectivity for hydrogenolysis versus ring hydrogenation.

elements.content: A carbon-supported cobalt (CSC) nanocomposite catalyst derived from ZIF-67 is reported for the conversion of VAL into vanillin. The CSC catalyst is stable under reaction conditions and offers excellent selectivity for vanillin (>95%). Furthermore, hydro-deoxygenation (HDO) of vanillin into 2-methoxy-4-methyl phenol was reported by Zhang and co-workers using Pd@MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H and Pd@UiO-66-NH2 catalysts. The reference Pd@MIL-101­(Cr) catalyst showed lower conversion of vanillin (67%) and selectivity of 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (58%) compared to Pd@MIL-101­(Cr)-SO3H and Pd@UiO-66-NH2. The higher activity for Pd@UiO-66-NH2 is observed because of higher adsorption of vanillin and vanillin alcohol due to the interaction of the hydrophilic substrate molecule and catalyst. This reveals that MOF-derived materials can also act as a promising catalyst for hydrogenolysis of lignin-derived chemicals.

elements.content: In conclusion, MOF-derived materials showed catalytic activity for many important biomass conversions including hydrolysis of saccharide, dehydration of sugars (xylose, glucose, and fructose) into furan, and upgradation of furans into fine chemicals. The good performance of MOF-derived materials on biomass conversion could be attributed to (a) the synergism between active sites and the functionalized ligand and (b) the separated active sites oriented from MOF.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, MOF-derived materials showed catalytic activity for many important biomass conversions including hydrolysis of saccharide, dehydration of sugars (xylose, glucose, and fructose) into furan, and upgradation of furans into fine chemicals. The good performance of MOF-derived materials on biomass conversion could be attributed to (a) the synergism between active sites and the functionalized ligand and (b) the separated active sites oriented from MOF.

elements.content: The MOF-derived materials inherit their porous and tunable structures from mother MOF, while the surface functionalization makes MOF materials more active, and the annulling process significantly improved stability and electrical conductivity of the material. As highlighted in this review, the diversity of MOFs has been demonstrated by a highly versatile combination between SBUs and organic ligands. The diversity of mother MOFs gives the MOF-derived materials excellent performance for many biomass reactions such as hydrolysis, dehydration, hydrogenation reactions of carbohydrates, and hydrogenation and oxidation reactions of furans (FAL and HMF). As a heterogeneous catalyst, MOF-derived materials demonstrate the recyclability and stability after recovery of samples from reaction media which is highly beneficial in industrial production. For the efficient catalytic valorization of biomass-concentrated substrate, solution selection will help for making economically promising and sustainable processes. Moreover, nonedible biomass should be preferred as a substrate over edible biomass which will not conflict with food demand. It is always desirable to practice the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass into sugars and furans in a one-pot fashion without using any pretreatment for reducing the cost of the experiment. Apart from these advantages of MOFs and MOF-derived materials for biomass conversion reactions, there are several future prospects described as follows: (1) There have been more than 20,000 kinds of MOFs which are not explored for MOF-derived materials yet. The potential and possibility of these MOFs in catalysis should be explored urgently. (2) The effect of physical properties of mother MOF on the catalysis over MOF-derived materials is seldom discussed. For example, a hollow MOF-derived material could be produced by synthesis of a layer of MOF on a soft template which could accelerate the catalytic activity by enhancing the diffusion of molecules. (3) It has been reported that the synthesis of alloy NPs or single atoms in the MOF shows good performance in chemical catalysis, photocatalysis, and oxygen reduction reaction. While to the best of our knowledge, none of the papers reported for biomass conversion using alloy NPs or single atom-containing MOF-derived materials. The higher activity of alloy NPs and single atoms are expected to accelerate the complex biomass conversion. (4) The serious weight loss after the annulling process increases the cost of MOF-derived materials, which is not favorable for industrial application. The development of large-scale synthesis processes with high yields to lower the cost of MOFs is also urgent. (5) Functionalized MOF-derived materials might not provide enough efficiency on more complicated cascade reactions such as conversion of glucose to FDCA including isomerization, dehydration, and three-step oxidations. A way is to combine MOFs and substrates such as carbon fiber cloth or silica NPs can help for improving catalytic efficiency.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions and Future Prospect

The MOF-derived materials inherit their porous and tunable structures from mother MOF, while the surface functionalization makes MOF materials more active, and the annulling process significantly improved stability and electrical conductivity of the material. As highlighted in this review, the diversity of MOFs has been demonstrated by a highly versatile combination between SBUs and organic ligands. The diversity of mother MOFs gives the MOF-derived materials excellent performance for many biomass reactions such as hydrolysis, dehydration, hydrogenation reactions of carbohydrates, and hydrogenation and oxidation reactions of furans (FAL and HMF). As a heterogeneous catalyst, MOF-derived materials demonstrate the recyclability and stability after recovery of samples from reaction media which is highly beneficial in industrial production. For the efficient catalytic valorization of biomass-concentrated substrate, solution selection will help for making economically promising and sustainable processes. Moreover, nonedible biomass should be preferred as a substrate over edible biomass which will not conflict with food demand. It is always desirable to practice the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass into sugars and furans in a one-pot fashion without using any pretreatment for reducing the cost of the experiment. Apart from these advantages of MOFs and MOF-derived materials for biomass conversion reactions, there are several future prospects described as follows: (1) There have been more than 20,000 kinds of MOFs which are not explored for MOF-derived materials yet. The potential and possibility of these MOFs in catalysis should be explored urgently. (2) The effect of physical properties of mother MOF on the catalysis over MOF-derived materials is seldom discussed. For example, a hollow MOF-derived material could be produced by synthesis of a layer of MOF on a soft template which could accelerate the catalytic activity by enhancing the diffusion of molecules. (3) It has been reported that the synthesis of alloy NPs or single atoms in the MOF shows good performance in chemical catalysis, photocatalysis, and oxygen reduction reaction. While to the best of our knowledge, none of the papers reported for biomass conversion using alloy NPs or single atom-containing MOF-derived materials. The higher activity of alloy NPs and single atoms are expected to accelerate the complex biomass conversion. (4) The serious weight loss after the annulling process increases the cost of MOF-derived materials, which is not favorable for industrial application. The development of large-scale synthesis processes with high yields to lower the cost of MOFs is also urgent. (5) Functionalized MOF-derived materials might not provide enough efficiency on more complicated cascade reactions such as conversion of glucose to FDCA including isomerization, dehydration, and three-step oxidations. A way is to combine MOFs and substrates such as carbon fiber cloth or silica NPs can help for improving catalytic efficiency.

elements.content: Overall, the well-developed MOF-derived materials make biomass conversion more efficient and valuable. Although there are still unknowns and the possibility of more MOF-derived materials waiting for exploration, we expect that future researchers could focus on these prospects to prepare high-performance MOF-derived materials for not only biomass conversion but also for electrochemistry, photocatalysis, and gas sensing applications.

Although there are still unknowns and the possibility of more MOF-derived materials waiting for exploration, we expect that future researchers could focus on these prospects to prepare high-performance MOF-derived materials for not only biomass conversion but also for electrochemistry, photocatalysis, and gas sensing applications.

elements.content: Babasaheb M. Matsagar received his Ph.D. from CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory (NCL), India, in 2016. Most of his research work is focused on the hydrolysis and dehydration reactions of saccharides, using acidic ionic liquids as a catalyst and developing sustainable biomass conversion methods for chemical and energy applications. At present, he is working as a postdoctoral researcher in the department of chemical engineering at National Taiwan University (NTU).

cln_elements.content: Xu’s group prepared MOF-derived PCs by pyrolysis of polymerized-furfuryl alcohol-stuffed MOF-5 and demonstrated a good performance on H2 storage. MOF-5 is composed of zinc oxide as SBUs and terephthalic acid as ligands. After pyrolysis under Ar flow at 1000 °C, the as-synthesized PCs showed amorphous carbon without the existence of a Zn element by X-ray diffractometry. The SBUs of MOF-5 (Zn4O) were reduced into a Zn metal at 800 °C followed by evaporation of the Zn metal. The MOF-5-derived PCs exhibit a high BET specific surface area of 2872 m2/g and a large pore volume of 2.06 cm3/g with hierarchical porous structures, which were comparable to the theoretical surface area of a double-sided separated graphitic sheet (2965 m2/g). Xu’s group further used ZIF-8 as a template, stuffed with polymerized-furfuryl alcohol followed by pyrolysis under Ar flow at 1000 °C. The furfuryl alcohol-stuffed ZIF-8-derived PCs showed a higher percentage of H2 storage (2.77%) than most of the carbon-based materials including activated carbons and MOF-5-derived carbons owing to the natural property of the ligands used for synthesizing ZIFs. The higher percentage of the C atom in the organic ligand (2-MIM) enhances the H2 storage of PCs.

cln_elements.content: Synthesis of MOF-derived materials by thermal treatment. (a) Direct pyrolysis of ZIF-8 into nitrogen-containing porous carbons (NPCs) as catalyst. (b) Direct pyrolysis of ZIF-8/ZIF-67 hybrid nanoparticles into Co single atoms on nitrogen-doped porous carbon (Co SAs/N–C). (c) High resolution TEM image of Co SAs/N–C. Red circles represent Co single atoms. (d) Corresponding EXAFS fitting curves with schematic model of Co SAs/N–C, Co (purple), N (blue), O (red), and C (gray). Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2016 John Wiley and Sons. (e) Direct calcination of MOF-embedded KIT-6 into metal-oxides@KIT-6 as catalyst. (f) High resolution TEM image of Co3O4@KIT-6 derived from ZIF-67@KIT-6. Reprinted with permission from ref . Copyright 2018 Royal Society of Chemistry.
